conversation.content: [exhausted] I've been driving since midnight to get this package to you, and the resort people at the front desk said you'd be here in the medical wing. [pause] They wouldn't tell me why you're not out on the slopes.
[bitter] So after four years of nothing, you show up with a delivery? [quietly] Could've just left it at the desk like any normal courier would do instead of hunting me down.

[frustrated] This isn't a normal delivery, it's from Dad's estate lawyer and it required personal signature within forty-eight hours. [sighs] Trust me, I wouldn't be here if there was any other option.
[shaky voice] Dad's estate? He's been dead for six months and they're just now sending things? [laughs] Perfect timing, really, just absolutely perfect considering everything else.
You're wearing a knee brace and your instructor jacket is hanging on that IV stand instead of on your shoulders, so clearly something happened that nobody bothered to mention to me.
[very quietly] Tore my ACL and MCL three days ago on a routine run with a student. [pause] Twenty years of skiing and I wipe out on a beginner slope.
Jesus, that's your whole career right there, isn't it? The thing you left everything behind for, including the family shipping business that Dad wanted you to take over.
The doctors say I'll never ski professionally again, might walk with a permanent limp if the surgery doesn't go perfectly. [trembling] So yeah, the career I chose over family is done.
[hesitantly] Look, I know we haven't talked since Dad's funeral, but this package, it's [exhales] apparently there's something in his will about the business that involves both of us.
Both of us? He made it crystal clear I was dead to him when I refused to take over the warehouse operations. [angry] Now what, he wants to twist the knife from beyond the grave?
[softly] Actually, no.

[confused] The letter inside says he left the entire business in both our names, fifty-fifty split, but only if we run it together for at least one year. [slowly] Otherwise it gets sold and the money goes to charity.
[frustrated] That manipulative old bastard, he knew exactly what he was doing, didn't he? [sighs] Forcing us back together when I can barely stand to look at you.
[quietly] You can barely stand to look at me? [louder] You're the one who told me I was selfish for following my dreams instead of staying in that windowless warehouse.
I was twenty-two and watching Dad cry because his favorite kid abandoned him for powder snow and tourist tips. [pause] What was I supposed to say?
[bitter] You were supposed to understand that not everyone wants to spend their life tracking packages and managing inventory systems. [softly] But now I guess that's exactly where I'm headed anyway.
[exhausted] We have seventy-two hours to decide according to this paperwork, and I've already been running the place solo for six months while you were living your mountain dream.
[shaky voice] A dream that just ended with me probably needing a cane before I'm forty. [sighs] Maybe Dad knew something we didn't about timing.

[hesitantly] The business has actually grown since you left, three new contracts with tech companies shipping specialized equipment. [quietly] Could use someone who understands customer service better than I do.
[very quietly] So we're really going to do this? [pause] Go back to that warehouse and pretend the last four years of silence didn't happen while we sort packages together?

scenario: A shipping clerk drives through the night to deliver an urgent legal document to their estranged sibling, a ski instructor at a mountain resort, only to discover the sibling has just suffered a career-ending injury.
